class).
The view associated with this item.

A bar item that provides a bar to contain other items.

inlineContent.text: An instance of the
class is called an
item
. It appears to the user on the Touch Bar, typically along with other items, within the (invisible) bounds of the view for an
object, called a
bar

You use an item by adding it or its identifier to one or another of a barâ€™s arrays, depending on your appâ€™s architecture and on the user customization you want to support. Because of the close interaction between bars and items, be sure you have read the overview for the
class before continuing here to learn about items.
AppKit provides a rich set of subclasses of
, each of which is described in the corresponding class reference document:
An
object (a
candidate-list item
), along with its delegate, provides a list of textual suggestions for the current text view
An
object (a
color picker item
) provides a system-defined color picker
An
object (a
custom item
) contains a responder of your choice, such as a view, a button, or a scrubber (an instance of the
class)
An
object (a
group item
) provides a bar to contain other items
An
object (a
popover item
) provides a two-state control that, when touched or pressed, expands into its second state, showing the contents of a bar it owns
An
object (a
sharing service picker item
), along with its delegate, provides a list of objects eligible for sharing
An
object (a
slider item
) provides a slider control for choosing a value in a range
The two most commonly-used item classes are
and
Refer to the following sample code projects which demonstrate how to use
and related classes:
â€”Shows how to create bars and items for use in the Touch Bar
â€”Shows how to add Touch Bar support to a typical Mac app
See
for a list of template images available for use in buttons or in other controls you add to your items.
You typically use a
custom item
(an instance of the
class) to hold a view. For example, to place a button in the Touch Bar, proceed as follows:
Use an
convenience initializer such as
to create and configure the button.
Set the
property for a custom item to point to the new button.
When you create custom items, itâ€™s important to use convenience initializers, available starting in macOS 10.12, for the
, and
classes. These initializers take care of sizing their controls correctly for the Touch Bar, and they configure appearance appropriately for the Touch Bar. For more on this, see
If you donâ€™t use the convenience initializers, itâ€™s your appâ€™s responsibility to ensure correct sizing and appearance.
A
popover item
(an instance of the
class)â€”the second commonly-used typeâ€”lets you provide a new bar (an
object) when a user taps, or presses-and-holds, on the collapsed representation of the popover item.
In its expanded state, a popover appears as an overlay above other items in the Touch Bar.
To show a bar when a user taps a popover item, specify a bar in the itemâ€™s
property. Enable press-and-hold by specifying a bar in the
property. The press-and-hold feature is suitable only for a simple popover, such as one that contains a single segmented control (an instance of the
class) or slider (an instance of the
class).
If your popover bar requires significant user interaction and contains many items or many scroll views, do not enable press-and-hold; doing so can result in an awkward user experience.
The system automatically shows a chevron in the popover item under the following conditions: You specify the same
object for both
and
properties,
and
you use the default view for the popover itemâ€™s
property.
If you provide a popover item that contains a scrubber (an
instance), youâ€™ll likely want to dismiss both the scrubber and the popover after the user makes their selection in the scrubber. A good approach to achieve this user interaction is to subclass
, employing your instance of the subclass as the scrubberâ€™s delegate. You can then configure the delegate object, within its
method, to call the popoverâ€™s
method.
If you place a segmented control in a bar for a popover item, take care
not
to use
option of the
enumeration because doing so interferes with the userâ€™s operation of the control.
To provide a
slider item
, always use the
class, which employs a standard slider but is optimized for user interaction with the Touch Bar. (That is, do not instead add an
object directly to a custom item.)
A
group item
(an instance of the
class) is a container that provides a bar, in its

property, with its own array of items. You can enable customization for the items in a groupâ€™s contained bar, in the same way you would for items directly within a top-level bar. Using a group item lets you provide different user customization rules for different parts of the Touch Bar, as described in

inlineContent.code: Group Item, Popover Item, and Composed Bar Customization

inlineContent.text: . Using a group item also lets you enable centering of the group within the Touch Bar, as described in â€œPrincipal Items.â€
A
spacing item
lets you add custom spacing between items in a bar. Specify a spacing item for a bar by assigning the
, or
identifier to an item, and adding that item to the barâ€™s items array. The system automatically instantiates and configures spacing items based on the identifiers you specify.
You must configure each item with a unique identifier, and can optionally assign a visibility priority or tag it as a principal item.
NSTouchBarItem identification.
You must provide a unique identifier for each item in the bar, apart from spacing items. Specify an identifier, of type
(called an
item identifier
), for each item when you initialize it. The item identifier serves as a persistable weak reference to the item.
For details on specifying item identifiers, see
and
The system uses item identifiers to populate bars and to track and record changes for user customization.
NSTouchBarItem priority for visibility.

If the system is showing a bar in the Touch Bar, but horizontal space is constrained and the bar defines more items than will fit, the system hides some of the items. You influence this hide/show behavior by setting a value for the
property of each item.
Lower-visibility-priority items get hidden by the system, as needed, before higher-visibility-priority items do.
To set visibility priority, use the constants in the
enumeration, or assign an integer value. The value
indicates â€œnormalâ€ visibility priority. Visibility priority increases with increasing numerical value. The
constant provides a value of
; the
constant, a value
. You can use integers outside of this range if you need to.
The system hides or shows groups of identical-priority items (defined within a single bar) together. The one exception to this rule is for items whose visibility priority is

; these items get hidden one-by-one, with the normal-priority item farthest to the right getting hidden first. If horizontal space later increases in the Touch Bar, and hidden, normal-priority items become eligible for display, the system first shows the most recently-hidden of those items.
Principal Items.
Within a bar, you can optionally specify an item as having special significance by employing the
property. The system attempts to center a principal item within the Touch Bar. If you want a group of items to appear centered in the Touch Bar, designate the group item (of type
) as the principal item.
If more than one bar in the responder chain is eligible to be visible in the Touch Bar, and more than one of those has a principal item, the system determines which one to center in the Touch Bar.
When using a button in a custom item, do not attempt to set the button titleâ€™s font. In the Touch Bar, the system specifies fonts for standard controls.
If you need to specify a font, such as for custom drawing, use the
class method (or related methods) of the
class. Use a font size of
to automatically obtain appropriate sizing for the Touch Bar.

If you use an image in a button or other control in the Touch Bar, take care to employ a template image. Template images in the Touch Bar respond automatically to system white-point changes, and automatically react to user interactions. The overview in this document lists the built-in Touch Bar template images.
To use your own image assets, use Retina-resolution images, designated as
in your asset catalog and with a maximum height of 30 points (corresponding to 60 pixels).
To set colors on objects within an

object, use AppKit named colors and use a bezel color property (available starting in macOS 10.12.1). Named colors appear correctly in the Touch Bar, support appearance vibrancy, and respond to system white-point changes. In a button or a segmented control, employ the bezel color property to ensure appropriate appearance in the Touch Bar.
To set the background color on a button within a custom item, use code like this:
To set color on text and glyphs in the Touch Bar, use the following colors from the
class:

The system automatically changes the relative brightness and the white-point of these colors, depending on the ambient light, and depending on other factors such as keyboard backlight level. Always use these colors, or colors that dynamically derive from these colors, for control backgrounds, text, icons, and glyphs in the Touch Bar.

content.text: Handling Touch Events in NSTouchBarItem Objects

inlineContent.text: The easiest way to handle touch events in an item is to use AppKit controls, such as by adding a button, a segmented control, or a scrubber to the item. Standard AppKit controls convey touch events to your specified targets automatically, so use standard controls whenever possible in your app.
If standard controls are insufficient, you can create composite views with a combination of standard controls, custom views, and gesture recognizers that you manually add to those custom views.
If you require the lowest-level of control for touch event processing, you can use the

class directly. You might go this route, for example, to provide good user feedback in the case of a control placed within a scroll view.Direct use of touch methods allows fine-grained control over interaction. You can, for example, highlight a control immediately upon a user touching it, and then remove the highlight if the user then, without lifting the finger, performs a scroll gesture.
If using the
class directly, be sure to implement the
responder method, because users can perform touch interactions that result in canceled touches.
macOS 10.12.1 supports the Touch Bar with enhancements to gesture recognizers, as described in â€œGesture recognizer supportâ€ in
. For an introduction to gesture recognizers, read â€œGesture Recognizersâ€ in
